message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and presentation are suggestive of Behcet's disease, which is known to cause uveitis as a complication. Other options are less commonly associated with Behcet's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the ulcer suggests the patient has aphthous stomatitis. The nodules on shins indicate erythema nodosum, which is commonly associated with aphthous stomatitis. The most likely complication from this condition is uveitis, as it is a common extra-intestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, which can also cause aphthous stomatitis. Deforming arthritis and gastrointestinal ulceration are other potential complications of inflammatory bowel disease, but are less specific to this patient’s current condition. Pulmonary embolism is not associated with aphthous stomatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest Behcet’s disease, which can lead to uveitis as a complication. Deforming arthritis and gastrointestinal ulceration are also possible complications, but uveitis is more common. Pulmonary embolism is less likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms strongly suggest Behçet's disease, which is characterized by recurrent oral ulcers and multiple other symptoms, including genital ulcers, skin lesions, and joint pain. Uveitis is a common complication of Behçet's disease, affecting up to 70% of patients. Deforming arthritis is less common, affecting only up to 50% of patients. Gastrointestinal ulceration and pulmonary embolism are not typically associated with Behçet's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination are consistent with Behcet’s disease, which is associated with recurrent oral and genital ulcers and tender nodules on the shins. Uveitis is a common complication of Behcet’s disease, while deforming arthritis, gastrointestinal ulceration, and pulmonary embolism are less common complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image of the nodule on the shin is consistent with erythema nodosum, which is commonly seen in patients with Behcet's syndrome. The patient has had recurrent painful ulcers in the mouth, which is a common symptom of Behcet's syndrome. Uveitis is a common complication of Behcet's syndrome. Deforming arthritis and gastrointestinal ulceration can occur but are not as common as uveitis, and pulmonary embolism is not a known complication of Behcet's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of Behçet's disease, which is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers and skin lesions such as tender nodules on the shins. The most common complication of Behçet's disease is uveitis, inflammation of the eye which can lead to blindness. Deforming arthritis can occur but it's less common. Gastrointestinal ulceration is another possible complication, but it's less common than uveitis. There is no indication of pulmonary embolism in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of Behcet’s syndrome, which is characterized by oral and genital ulcers and skin lesions. Among the possible complications, uveitis is the most common and occurs in up to 70% of patients with Behcet’s syndrome. Deforming arthritis is less common, and gastrointestinal ulceration and pulmonary embolism are not typical complications of the syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Behcet's disease, which causes oral and genital ulcers and skin lesions such as the tender nodules on the patient's shins. Uveitis (inflammation of the eye) is a common complication of Behcet's disease, occurring in over 50% of patients. Deforming arthritis and gastrointestinal ulceration can also occur, but they are not as common or as specific to Behcet's disease as uveitis. Pulmonary embolism is not a known complication of Behcet's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with Behçet Syndrome, which can cause oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and skin nodules. Uveitis is a common complication of Behçet Syndrome, affecting around 25-75% of patients, and can lead to vision loss if left untreated. Deforming arthritis may occur, but it is less common than uveitis. Gastrointestinal ulceration and pulmonary embolism are not typically associated with Behçet Syndrome.
